Fig. 1 TPR profiles of as-prepared CuO/SiO2-Q6 samples with different CuO contents. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of N2 carrier gas flow rate in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6. The dotted lines present the selectivity to decanal, and the solid lines present the conversion of 1-decanol. Reaction conditions: reaction temperature, 275 oC; W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of contact time in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6. Reaction conditions: reaction temperature, 275oC; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; N2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1. The sample was reduced by hydrogen at 300 oC for 1 h before reaction. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of reaction temperature in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6. The dotted lines present the selectivity to decanal, and the solid lines present the conversion of 1-decanol. Reaction conditions: W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; N2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1. In the reaction at 325 oC, the sample was reduced by hydrogen at 325 oC. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD profiles of the fresh and the used 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples. The fresh sample was reduced at 300 °C for 1 h before the XRD analysis. Reaction conditions for the used 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples: W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; N2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1; TOS, 5 h. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 FTIR spectra of fresh and used 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 catalysts. Reaction conditions for the used catalysts: W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; N2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1; TOS, 5 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TG curves of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 used with different TOS. Reaction conditions for the 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples: reaction temperature, 275 °C; W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; N2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Changes in carbon content deposited on the10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples used at different TOS. Reaction conditions for the 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples are the same with those in Figs. 7 and 9. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TG curves of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 used at 275 and 325 °C with different TOS. Reaction conditions for the 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 sample: W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; N2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Effect of carrier gas in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6. Reaction conditions: W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; flow rate of carrier gas, 30 cm3min−1. Reaction temperature: 275 oC in N2 and 325 °C in H2. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over a regenerated 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 catalyst. Reaction conditions: W/F, 0.29 h; feed rate of 1-decanol, 1.7 g h−1; N2 flow rate, 30 cm3 min−1.The 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 sample was used after a reaction at 325 °C and was heated in air at 400 °C for 3 h. Advantages of using Cu/SiO2 catalyst for vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol into decanal Daolai Sun a b Takuya Misu b Yasuhiro Yamada b Satoshi Sato b ⁎ a National-Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for Energy Conservation of Chemical Process Integration and Resources Utilization, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, 300130, China National-Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for Energy Conservation of Chemical Process Integration and Resources Utilization, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China b Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba, 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering Chiba University Chiba 263-8522 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to form decanal was performed over various supported Cu catalysts such as Cu/SiO2, Cu/ZnO, and Cu/Al2O3. Among the catalysts tested in this work, Cu/SiO2 showed a high and stable catalytic activity for the conversion of 1-decanol to form decanal, and 77.4% conversion of 1-decanol with 98.4% selectivity to decanal was achieved over Cu/SiO2 catalyst in N2 flow at 275 °C. The physical properties of SiO2 support affected the catalytic activity, and the SiO2 with a surface area of 451 m2 g−1 and an averaged pore size of 6 nm was preferable for the formation of decanal. The catalytic reaction was regulated by equilibrium: the pressure equilibrium constant, K p, was estimated to be 0.30 atm at 275 °C. The deactivation of the catalyst was observed in N2 flow at 325 °C, while it was not observed in H2. The activity of the deactivated catalyst was completely recovered in N2 at 275 °C after calcination in air at 400 °C followed by H2 reduction. Based on the DRIFT and TG analyses, hydrocarbon species were accumulated on the catalyst surface in the initial period of the reaction. In addition, it was found that the dehydrogenation of the hydrocarbon species accumulated on the catalyst mainly caused the catalytic deactivation. Keywords 1-decanol Dehydrogenation Decanal Cu/SiO2 catalyst Catalytic deactivation 1 Introduction Aldehydes are important chemicals widely used in the petrochemical industry, and the oxidation of primary aliphatic alcohols is an effective method for producing aldehydes [1,2]. In traditional processes, alcohols are oxidized to form aldehydes by some inorganic oxidants such as K2Cr2O7, K2CrO4, and KMnO4 [3–6]. Because these processes suffer from the use of stoichiometric inorganic oxidants as well as the by-production of the large amount of toxic solid waste, the development of alternative processes is highly required. The oxidation of alcohols by oxygen and hydrogen peroxide has been reported as an alternative method for producing aldehydes, whereas the process generally suffers from the low selectivity to aldehydes due to the excessive oxidation [7–9]. The acceptorless dehydrogenative oxidation, i.e. simple dehydrogenation, of alcohols is another method for producing aldehydes [10]. In contrast to the above-mentioned two processes, the dehydrogenation of alcohols, especially a vapor-phase process, is friendly to the environment, and high selectivities to aldehydes can also be achieved [11–13]. Furthermore, the dehydrogenation of alcohols also forms H2, and there is almost no waste of the reactant in the dehydrogenation process. Therefore, the dehydrogenation of alcohols to form aldehydes is an attractive process, and it has attracted much attention. Cu-based solid catalysts have been widely investigated in the heterogeneous dehydrogenation of alcohols to form aldehydes, and various supported Cu catalysts exhibit high catalytic performance [14]. Because of the important use of formaldehyde and acetaldehyde, the dehydrogenation of methanol and ethanol are mostly investigated and reported. Shelepova et al. studied the vapor-phase dehydrogenation of methanol over Cu/SiO2 [15,16] and Cu/C [16], and indicated that the diminished interaction of Cu with the support was responsible for a high catalytic activity. In the vapor-phase dehydrogenation of ethanol to form acetaldehyde, a Cu/C/SiO2 catalyst provides 98% selectivity to acetaldehyde with an initial conversion of 83% at 260 °C [11], while potassium-modified Cu/SiO2 [12] and Cu/MgAlOx [13] catalysts provide 99% selectivity with an initial conversion of ca. 65% and 75% at 300 °C, respectively. However, all the catalysts are not stable, and gradual decrease in conversion of ethanol is observed. In the case of Cu/MgAlOx, even a decrease of 30% in the conversion of ethanol is observed within 4 h of time on stream (TOS) [13]. The catalytic stability is an important factor for an industrial catalyst, whereas few studies focus on studying the deactivation behavior of the Cu-based catalysts in the vapor-phase dehydrogenation of alcohols to form aldehydes. In contrast to short-chain primary aliphatic alcohols, the dehydrogenation of long-chain primary aliphatic alcohols is less reported. Long-chain aldehydes are widely used in the production of perfumes and colognes [17], and the investigation of the dehydrogenation of long-chain primary aliphatic alcohols to form long-chain aldehydes is of great importance in the fine chemical industry [18]. Shi et al. have performed a liquid-phase transfer dehydrogenation of some long-chain aliphatic alcohols, such as 1-octanol and 1-decanol, in which Cu/La2O3 is used as the catalyst and styrene is used as the hydrogen acceptor [19]. The selectivities to the corresponding aldehydes are higher than 97% at 250 °C, whereas the conversion of 1-octanol and 1-decanol is 63% and 45% at a TOS of 2 and 10 h, respectively. Crivello et al. have reported that Cu-supported hydrotalcitelike compounds exhibit high catalytic activity in the vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-octanol, whereas the catalysts are not stable, and higher than 15% decrease in conversion is observed within only 4 h of TOS even in the case using the optimized catalyst [20]. Thus, a long-chain alcohol is more difficult than short-chain alcohols to be converted to produce the corresponding aldehyde. In this study, vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to form decanal was performed over several Cu-based catalysts, as shown in Scheme 1 . The effect of the catalyst properties on the catalytic activity as well as the effect of the reaction conditions was investigated. Furthermore, the behavior of the catalytic deactivation was studied and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples 1-Decanol was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., which was used as the reactant in the catalytic reaction without further purification. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O were also purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., and they were used as the precursors of the corresponding metals. Three different kinds of silicas (CARiACT Q3, Q6 and Q10) were supplied by Fuji Silycia Chemical Ltd., Japan. Q3, Q6 and Q10 have a specific surface area of 705, 451, and 295 m2 g−1 and a mean pore diameter of 3, 6 and 10 nm, respectively. γ-Al2O3 (N611 N) with a specific surface area of 166 m2 g−1 was purchased from Nikki Chemical Co., Ltd., Japan. ZnO was purchased from Kanto Kagaku Co., Ltd., Japan. All the metal-supported catalysts were prepared through an incipient wetness impregnation method. Firstly, a prescribed amount of metal nitrate was added to the distillated water in order to prepare a metal nitrate aqueous solution. Secondly, the solution was added to a support, and water was evaporated by illuminating samples using a 350-W electric light bulb at ambient pressure and 70 °C. Thirdly, the samples were dried at 110 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried samples were calcined at 400 °C for 3 h. Hereafter, the as-prepared catalysts are denominated as xA/B, where A indicates the species of the supported metal; B indicates the species of the support; x means the weight percentage of the supported metal oxide of A. For example, 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 means a catalyst with 10 wt.% CuO loaded on SiO2-Q6 support, where a CuO content of 10 wt.% corresponds to a Cu content of 8.2 wt.%. 2.2 Catalytic reaction Vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol was performed in a fixed-bed down-flow glass-tube reactor under ambient N2 atmospheric conditions. Firstly, a catalyst of 0.5 g was placed on the catalyst bed in the reactor, and a pretreatment of the catalyst was performed in an H2 flow of 30 cm3 min−1 at 300 °C for 1 h. Then, the temperature was changed to a prescribed reaction temperature, and N2 carrier gas was flowed at a flow rate of 30 cm3 min−1 instead of H2. Finally, 1-decanol without dilution was fed through the top of the reactor at a liquid feed rate of 1.7 g h−1 together with N2 flow, and the liquid effluents were collected in an ice-water trap every hour. The products in the effluents were identified using a gas chromatography with mass-spectrometer (GCMS-QP5050A, Shimadzu). The effluent was analyzed by a gas chromatography with a flame ionization detector (GC-14B, Shimadzu) with a capillary column of TC-WAX (GL-Science, a length of 30 m). The conversion and selectivity were calculated as the following equations: (1) C o n v e r s i o n % = ( 1 - m o l e s o f t h e r e c o v e r e d r e a c t a n t m o l e s o f t h e f e d r e a c t a n t ) × 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y % = m o l e s o f t h e s p e c i f i c p r o d u c t m o l e s o f t h e f e d r e a c t a n t - m o l e s o f t h e r e c o v e r e d r e a c t a n t × 100 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker) using Cu Kα radiation. The thermo gravimetry (TG) was performed in air atmosphere using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku) for evaluating the amount of carbon species accumulated on the catalyst surface during the catalytic reaction. The analysis conditions are as follows: sample weight, ca. 10 mg; the rate of the temperature increment, 5 °C min−1; heating range, from the room temperature to 900 °C. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed in order to understand the reduction behavior of the as-prepared catalysts. The TPR analysis was performed using the following conditions: flow rate of H2/N2 ( = 1/9) mixed gas, 10 cm3 min-1; heating rate, 5 °C min-1; heating range, from 25 to 900 °C. The details of the TPR analysis are described elsewhere [21]. The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) spectra of the prepared samples were recorded on a FT/IR-4200 spectrometer (JASCO). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Dehydrogenation of 1-decanol over various supported metal catalysts Table 1 lists the reaction results of the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol over several supported metal catalysts. The reaction was performed at 275 °C under ambient N2 atmosphere with a flow rate of 30 cm3 min−1. The catalyst loading and the feed rate of 1-decanol was 0.5 g and 1.7 g h−1, respectively, and the contact time (W/F) was 0.29 h where W and F are a weight of catalyst loaded in the reactor and a liquid feed rate of 1-decanol, respectively. Considering that the support with strong acidity would catalyze the dehydration of 1-decanol to form decene, some neutral or weak acidic supports, such as ZnO and SiO2, were chosen as the supports. In all the tests, decanal was generated as the main product, while decanoic acid, decyl decanoate and decene were detected as the by-products with different amounts. Scheme 2 shows the possible formation routes of all the detected products. Decanal is formed by the direct dehydrogenation of 1-decanol, and decene is formed by the dehydration of 1-decanol. Tishchenko esterification of aldehydes are readily catalyzed by acid-base bifunctional catalysts [22], and decyl decanoate is proposed to be produced through the Tishchenko esterification of decanal. Decanoic acid is possibly produced by the direct oxidation of decanal, while the hydrolysis of decyl decanoate also probably produces decanoic acid. As shown in Table 1, 5Cu/Al2O3 gave a high 1-decanol conversion of 77.6%, whereas the selectivity to decanal was only 76.4%. The selectivities to decanoic acid, decyl decanoate, decene and undetected products over 5Cu/Al2O3 were higher than those over 5Cu/ZnO and 5Cu/SiO2-Q6. It is proposed that the Al2O3 with relatively strong acidity would take part in the formation of the various by-products. 5Cu/ZnO showed a decanal selectivity of 94.6%, while the conversion of 1-decanol was as low as 26.1%. Among the tested catalysts, 5Cu/SiO2-Q6 showed the best catalytic performance, which gave the highest decanal selectivity of 98.9% with a relatively high conversion of 71.8%. In contrast to the Cu-based catalysts, Co- and Ni-supported catalysts showed poor activity and gave the 1-decanol conversion lower than 10%. The reduction temperature of 300 °C is considered to be not enough for reducing Co and Ni oxides to their metal state completely, which leads to the poor activity [23]. In our previous studies dealing with some dehydration processes such as the dehydration of 2-buten-1-ol to form 1,3-butadiene [24], we have found that the use of H2 as the carrier gas is beneficial for improving the stability of the supported metal catalysts. In particular, the supported metal together with H2 can inhibit the formation of coke that leads to a stable catalytic activity. Niu et al. reported the dehydration of glycerol to form acetol over Cu/SiO2 catalyst, which showed a relatively stable activity in H2 atmosphere in contrast to N2 atmosphere [25]. Therefore, the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol was also performed over 5Cu/SiO2-Q6 in H2 atmosphere in order to evaluate the catalyst deactivation behavior in H2 atmosphere. Unfortunately, the use of H2 decreased the conversion of 1-decanol in this case because high H2 partial pressure affected the reaction equilibrium and promoted the reverse reaction in such a dehydrogenation process. In addition, the selectivity to decanal in H2 atmosphere was also low in contrast to that in N2 atmosphere. Therefore, N2 was mainly used as the carrier gas in the following study. 3.2 Dehydrogenation of 1-decanol over catalysts with different metal loadings and different SiO2 supports Since SiO2 showed a good performance as a support (Table 1), we further prepared catalysts using different SiO2 supports and evaluated the suitable Cu loading in each case. As shown in Table 2 , SiO2-Q6 showed a better catalytic performance than either SiO2-Q3 or SiO2-Q10 at the same Cu loading. The specific surface area and the pore size are two important factors for SiO2 supports, and different reactions always require different properties of SiO2. We have used SiO2-Q3, SiO2-Q6, and SiO2-Q10 as supports or catalysts in some dehydration reactions [26,27]. In the cyclodehydration of levulinic acid to form angelica lactones [27], SiO2-Q3 with the largest specific surface area showed the best performance as a catalyst. On the other hand, in the aldol condensation of butanal to form 2-ethyl-2-hexenal [26], SiO2-Q10 with the largest pore size showed the best performance. In the present study, the type of SiO2 support did not significantly affect the selectivity, whereas it influenced the conversion of 1-decanol: in contrast to SiO2-Q3- and SiO2-Q10-supported Cu catalysts, SiO2-Q6-supported Cu catalysts gave the highest conversion of 1-decanol at the same Cu loading. This result indicates that SiO2 with a surface area of 451 m2 g−1 and an averaged pore size of 6 nm is preferable for the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to form decanal. It is reasonable that a large surface area is effective for dispersing Cu particles, while a large pore size is effective for the diffusion of the reactants as well as the products. Since the specific surface area and the pore size are conflicting factors, the SiO2-Q6 with a moderate specific surface area and a moderate pore size shows the best performance. The loading amount of Cu in each support did not significantly affect the selectivity to decanal, whereas it affected the conversion of 1-decanol (Table 2). The suitable loading of Cu was 10% in the case of SiO2-Q6, and a large Cu loading such as 20% decreased the conversion of 1-decanol. Fig. 1 shows the TPR profiles of Cu/SiO2-Q6 with different CuO loadings. Two reduction peaks can be observed in each profile. The reduction temperatures are 214 and 297 °C for 5Cu/SiO2-Q6, 227 and 316 °C for 10Cu/SiO2-Q6, 228 and 401 °C for 15Cu/SiO2-Q6, and 236 and 408 °C for 20Cu/SiO2-Q6. The two peaks are proposed to be attributed to the reduction of CuO to Cu2O and the reduction of Cu2O to Cu, respectively [28]. It is obvious that high reduction temperatures were required for the samples with large Cu loadings, indicating that large Cu particles were formed at large Cu loadings. Because the catalysts were reduced at 300 °C before starting the reaction, CuO in the catalysts with a large Cu loading was not possibly reduced to Cu completely, which led to a relatively low catalytic activity. 3.3 The reactions over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 with different calcination and reduction temperatures Since calcination temperature is generally an important factor for metal catalysts, the effect of calcination temperature was studied. 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples calcined at different temperatures were tested in order to understand the effect of the calcination temperature. Table 3 shows the reaction results of the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 calcined at different calcination temperatures. The highest selectivity to decanal was recorded at 98.4% over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 calcined at 400 °C, while the conversion of 1-decanol decreased with increasing the calcination temperature. The conversion of 1-decanol was ca. 77% at a calcination temperature range of 350–450 °C, whereas it significantly decreased to 66.3% at a calcination temperature of 500 °C. It is proposed that a high calcination temperature such as 500 °C would promote the agglomeration of Cu, and therefore, decrease the catalytic activity. As a result, 400 °C was the suitable calcination temperature for achieving decanal from 1-decanol. Table 4 shows the effect of the reduction temperature of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol. The reduction temperature did not significantly affect the selectivity to decanal, whereas it affected the conversion of 1-decanol. The catalyst reduced at 200 °C showed the lowest conversion of 1-decanol. As mentioned in Section 3.2, the TPR profile of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 shows two reduction peaks at 227 and 316 °C, respectively. Therefore, 200 °C would not be enough to reduce copper oxide to copper metal completely, which led to the low activity of the catalyst. On the other hand, a high reduction temperature such as 500 °C also decreased the conversion of 1-decanol, which could be caused by agglomeration of Cu during the reduction at a high temperature. The suitable reduction temperature of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 was found to be 300–350 °C, and the catalysts reduced at 300 and 350 °C could provide 1-decanol conversions higher than 77% with decanal selectivities higher than 97%. 3.4 Dehydrogenation of 1-decanol under several reaction conditions In order to study the effect of the reaction conditions, some reaction factors such as the flow rate of N2, the contact time (W/F), and the reaction temperature were investigated. Fig. 2 shows the effect of the flow rate of the N2 carrier gas in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6. The reactions were performed at 275 °C with a W/F of 0.29 h. The flow rate of N2 did not obviously affect the selectivity to decanal, whereas it affected the conversion of 1-decanol: the conversion of 1-decanol increased with increasing the N2 flow rate up to 30 cm3 min−1. The dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to form decanal is a reaction with increased number of molecules, and the decrement of the partial pressure of the reaction system would lead to the shift of the reaction equilibrium. The pressure equilibrium constant K p can be calculated by the following equation: (3) K p = P decanal × P H 2 P 1 − decanol where P i (atm) is a partial pressure of the component of i. It is obvious that the increment of N2 flow would decrease the partial pressure of decanal, H2, and 1-decanol. Because K p is a constant at a determined temperature, the reaction equilibrium would shift from the left side to the right side, which is consistent with Le Chatelier's principle. This result indicates that a high flow rate is effective for promoting the conversion of 1-decanol. Fig. 3 shows the effect of the contact time for the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 at 275 °C with a N2 flow rate of 30 cm3 min−1. The conversion of 1-decanol increased with increasing the W/F up to 0.59 h, and the highest conversion was achieved at 80.6%. Further increment of the W/F did not increase the conversion, which kept at the high value of 80% at a W/F of 1.18 h, indicating that the equilibrium conversion of 1-decanol was 80.6% at 275 °C. On the other hand, the selectivity to decanal gradually decreased with increasing the W/F. As mentioned in Section 3.1, the SiO2 samples used in the present study have weak acidity, which has been confirmed by NH3-TPD analysis in our previous report [27]. Acidic catalysts are generally active for dehydration processes such as the dehydration of 2-buten-1-ol to 1,3-butadiene over SiO2-Al2O3 [24], therefore, SiO2 would be active for the dehydration of 1-decanol to form decene. Additionally, since Tishchenko esterification of butanal proceeds over SiO2 [26], it is reasonable that SiO2-Q6 would be active for the Tishchenko esterification of decanal to form decyl decanoate. The increment of the contact time would promote the side reactions over SiO2-Q6, therefore, decrease the selectivity to decanal (Fig. 3). Additionally, we calculated the pressure equilibrium constant, K p, using the data achieved in the reaction over SiO2-Q6 at 275 °C and a W/F of 0.59 h (the data in Fig. 3). The experimental K p was estimated to be 0.30 atm. Fig. 4 shows the effect of the reaction temperature in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6. The reactions were performed at a W/F of 0.29 h with a N2 flow rate of 30 cm3 min−1. The selectivity to decanal was not obviously affected by the reaction temperature, while the initial conversion of 1-decanol increased with increasing the reaction temperature, indicating that the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol is endothermic and a high temperature is effective for promoting the conversion of 1-decanol. On the other hand, the conversion of 1-decanol was stable at low reaction temperatures such as 250 and 275 oC, whereas it gradually decreased with TOS at high reaction temperatures such as 300 and 325 oC. The conversion of 1-decanol was even decreased from 82.2 to 35.8% within 5 h at 325 oC. As a result, a moderate reaction temperature such as 275 oC was suitable for achieving both a high and a stable catalytic activity. Further discussion concerted with the catalytic deactivation is presented in Section 3.5. 3.5 Consideration on the catalytic deactivation Catalyst stability is an important factor for evaluating a catalyst or a catalytic process, whereas the catalyst deactivation behavior in the dehydrogenation of long-chain primary aliphatic alcohols is less reported. In this study, the deactivation behavior of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal was studied in detail. Fig. 5 shows the XRD profiles of the fresh and the used 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples, which were used at 275 and 325 °C with a TOS of 5 h. The fresh sample was reduced in H2 before the XRD analysis, and it showed diffraction reflected at 43.5° and 50.4°, which were attributed to Cu metal (JCPDS file 4-836). The samples used at 275 and 325 °C showed similar XRD profiles compared with that of the fresh one, indicating that Cu particles were maintained as a metal state without significant changes after the reaction at both 275 and 325 °C. DRIFT analysis of the used 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples were conducted in order to clarify the carbonaceous compounds accumulated on the samples (Fig. 6 ). The peaks at 2856, 2926 and 2960 cm−1 were observed in the spectra of both the samples used at 275 and 325 °C, while they were not observed in the spectrum of the fresh sample. The peak at 2960 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of CH3, and the peaks at 2856 and 2926 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of CH2 and/or CH3 [29,30]. This result indicates that hydrocarbon species are accumulated on the used catalyst. Additionally, as mentioned in Sections 3.2 and 3.4, aldehydes are readily dimerized over acid catalysts such as SiO2 with weak acidity [26]. Therefore, the accumulated hydrocarbon species are proposed to be the oligomer or the polymer of decanal. However, unfortunately, the difference in the DRIFT spectra between the samples used at 275 and 325 °C was so small that it is insufficient to discuss the component of the carbonaceous compounds. Since the coke formation on the catalyst surface generally leads to the catalytic deactivation, TG analysis of the used 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples were conducted for evaluating the amount of the carbon species accumulated on the catalyst surface. In order to understand the carbon accumulation behavior, the 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples used at 275 °C with different TOS were analyzed by TG (Fig. 7 ). The fresh sample shows an increment in weight at 100–450 °C, which is attributed to the oxidation of Cu to CuO. All the used 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 samples have a steep decrease in weight at a temperature range of 200–400 °C, which is attributed to the decomposition of accumulated carbon species [31]. It is obvious that the weight loss increased with increasing TOS, indicating that the amount of accumulated carbon species increased with increasing TOS. On the other hand, in contrast to that at a long TOS, the accumulation speed of carbon species was fast at a short TOS, indicating that the amount of carbon species did not linearly increase with TOS. In order to confirm the accumulation speed of carbon species, the weight content of carbon in the used 10CuO/Q6-400 samples with different TOS was summarized in Fig. 8 . The weight content of carbon in the used samples increased rapidly with increasing TOS up to the initial 15 min, and the weight content of carbon was 14.7% at a TOS of 15 min. The accumulation speed of carbon species suddenly became slow after 15 min of TOS, and the weight content of carbon at 300 min was 15.7%, which was only 1.0% higher than that at 15 min. This result demonstrates that carbon species were rapidly accumulated on the catalyst surface in the initial period of the reaction, and the accumulation speed of carbon species became slow after the initial period of the reaction. From the above analysis results, it is known that in the case of the 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 catalyst used at 275 °C, a large amount of carbon species had been accumulated on the catalyst surface within only 15 min, whereas the catalytic activity of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 was still stable from 15 to 300 min of TOS (Fig. 4). This result indicates that the carbon species accumulated at 275 oC did not affect the catalytic stability. On the other hand, as mentioned in Section 3.4, the catalytic stability of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 at 325 °C gradually decreased with TOS, indicating that the carbon accumulation behavior would be different at a high temperature such as 325 °C. In order to confirm this issue, the carbon accumulation behavior at 275 °C and 325 °C in the TG analysis was compared in Fig. 9 . At the same TOS within 15 min, the weight loss of the sample used at 275 °C was at most 1.8% larger than that used at 325 °C, indicating that, at a low temperature of 275 °C, ca. 2% or more carbon species are accumulated on the catalyst in the initial period of the reaction. A change in the weight of carbon with TOS at 325 °C is also drawn in Fig. 8. It is generally accepted that carbon is easily accumulated on the catalyst surface at high temperatures, and we have confirmed it in some dehydration processes such as the dehydration of 1,2-propanediols to form corresponding aldehydes [31]. In the present study, however, the carbon species accumulated at 325 oC with a smaller amount than 275 oC seems to contribute to the serious catalytic deactivation (Fig. 4). This could be explained by the following consideration: the carbonaceous compounds would form coke in N2 at a high temperature of 325 oC. The coke formation, i.e. dehydrogenation of carbonaceous compounds, reduces hydrogen from the carbonaceous compounds. The weight loss of the sample used at 325 °C could be smaller than that used at 275 °C (Fig. 8) because the dehydrogenation of carbonaceous compounds proceeds preferably at a high temperature of 325 °C. Therefore, it is reasonable that the component of carbon species at 325 oC would be different from that at 275 oC, and that the carbon species, i.e. coke, formed through dehydrogenation could affect the catalytic deactivation. As shown in Fig. 4, the catalyst was gradually deactivated in an N2 flow at 325 °C. To ensure that the deactivation was caused by the dehydrogenation of the accumulated hydrocarbon species, the reaction was performed over 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 in a hydrogen flow of 30 cm3 min−1 at 325 °C. Fig. 10 shows the catalytic activity of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 in an H2 flow at 325 °C. The conversion was stable in the same way as the reaction in N2 flow at 275 °C. This indicates that the atmospheric hydrogen prevents the dehydrogenation of the accumulated hydrocarbon species even at 325 °C. In addition, the conversion in H2 at 325 °C was lower than those in N2 at 275 °C because of the limitation of equilibrium, whereas the selectivity to decanal gradually increased with TOS. Furthermore, we performed an additional reaction: the 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 catalyst deactivated in N2 at 325 °C for 5 h was regenerated by calcination in air at 400 °C for 3 h, and the regenerated catalyst was further tested in N2 at 275 °C. As shown in Fig. 11 , the catalytic activity of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 was recovered by calcination, and it was stable at 275 °C for 5 h. This result demonstrates that the catalytic deactivation in N2 at 325 °C is mainly caused by the dehydrogenation of the hydrocarbon species accumulated on the catalyst surface, and the catalytic activity can be recovered through removing the carbon species by calcination. It is speculated that the dehydrogenation could produce coke from the hydrocarbon species deposited on the copper metals in N2 at 325 °C. 4 Conclusions Vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to form decanal was performed over several supported Cu catalysts such as Cu/SiO2, Cu/ZnO, and Cu/Al2O3. Among the tested catalysts, Cu/SiO2 showed the best performance for the formation of decanal. SiO2 with a surface area of 451 m2 g−1 and an averaged pore size of 6 nm was preferable as a support, and the suitable loading of Cu was determined to be 10 wt.% of CuO. The proper calcination temperature and reduction temperature of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 were found to be 400 and 300 °C, respectively. 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 showed stable catalytic activity with 77.4% conversion of 1-decanol and 98.4% selectivity to decanal in N2 flow at 275 °C. Increasing the flow rate of the carrier gas was effective in improving the conversion of 1-decanol because it led to the shift of the equilibrium in the dehydrogenation from the left side to the right. At 275 °C, the pressure equilibrium constant, K p, was estimated to be 0.30 atm. The catalytic activity of 10Cu/SiO2-Q6 seriously decreased with time on stream in N2 flow at 325 °C, whereas it was stable in H2 at 325 °C. In the TG analyses of the used catalysts, it was revealed that carbonaceous compounds were accumulated on the catalyst surface in the initial period of the reaction. The carbonaceous compounds were determined to be hydrocarbon species through DRIFT analysis. The hydrocarbon species accumulated on the catalyst deactivated at 325 °C could be removed by calcination in air at 400 °C, and the catalytic activity was completely recovered at 275 °C. It was proposed that the coke formation, i.e. dehydrogenation of the hydrocarbon species accumulated on the catalyst surface, could be the cause of the catalytic deactivation in N2 flow at a high temperature of 325 °C. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to form decanal was performed over various supported Cu catalysts such as Cu/SiO2, Cu/ZnO, and Cu/Al2O3. Among the catalysts tested in this work, Cu/SiO2 showed a high and stable catalytic activity for the conversion of 1-decanol to form decanal, and 77.4% conversion of 1-decanol with 98.4% selectivity to decanal was achieved over Cu/SiO2 catalyst in N2 flow at 275 °C. The physical properties of SiO2 support affected the catalytic activity, and the SiO2 with a surface area of 451 m2 g−1 and an averaged pore size of 6 nm was preferable for the formation of decanal. The catalytic reaction was regulated by equilibrium: the pressure equilibrium constant, K p, was estimated to be 0.30 atm at 275 °C. The deactivation of the catalyst was observed in N2 flow at 325 °C, while it was not observed in H2. The activity of the deactivated catalyst was completely recovered in N2 at 275 °C after calcination in air at 400 °C followed by H2 reduction. Based on the DRIFT and TG analyses, hydrocarbon species were accumulated on the catalyst surface in the initial period of the reaction. In addition, it was found that the dehydrogenation of the hydrocarbon species accumulated on the catalyst mainly caused the catalytic deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Advantages of using Cu/SiO2 catalyst for vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol into decanal
